imt: Indra.\textsc{voc.sg} Soma-\textsc{nom.m.sg}  do-\textsc{perf.m.pl}  barley.\textsc{nom.m.pl} eat-\textsc{inf}  you.\textsc{gen.sg} horse-\textsc{dat.sg}
src: indra sóma-ḥ  \textbf{kṛ-tā́} dhānā́ át-tave  te hári-bhyāṃ
trs: The Barhis has been strewn for thee, O Indra; the Soma  has been pressed (into an extract). The barley grains  have been prepared for thy two bay-horses to eat.' (Ṛgveda 3.35.7)

imt: man-\textsc{inst.pl}  wash-\textsc{perf.m.sg}  press-\textsc{perf.m.sg}  stone-\textsc{inst.pl}  wool-\textsc{gen.sg}  filter-\textsc{inst.pl}  strain-\textsc{perf.m.sg}
trs: It (the Soma) has been washed  by men, pressed with the help of stones, strained with  wool-filters.' (Ṛgveda 8.2.2)
Soma rests (is supported) in the heaven.' (Ṛgveda 10.85.1)
Then he \textit{stole} that cow, but \textit{did} not \textit{consider} the
Jaratkāru went to heaven accompanied by his ancestors.' (\textit{Mahābhārata} 1.130.43c)
And King  Seṇiya \textit{reached} that place.' (\textit{Vasudevahiṃḍī} KH. 17.1)
That running one \textit{noticed} an old well covered with grass.' (\textit{Vasudevahiṃḍī} KH. 8.6)

Does the young (rising) sun not destroy darkness? Does the young fire (spark) not burn down the forest? Does a young lion (cub) not shatter the elephant? Does the young snake not bite?' (\textit{Paumacariu}  2.21.6.9)
One who gives up eating in the evening (he) attains a spotless body and name.'  (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.34.8.8)
Lord Suggiu remembers you.'  (\textit{Paumacariu} 3.45.10.8)
If I do not capture you tomorrow\dots{}' (\textit{Paumacariu} 3.49.20.3)
(The one) who adores another one besides me\dots{}'  (\textit{Paumacariu}  2.25.1.9)
We are going to our forest-exile.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.23.14.3)
What crime have we done?' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.2.13.9)
That, which  you thought (would happen),  happened.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 3.47.9.6)
Rām drove me out (of Ayodhya) without any reason.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 5.81.13.8)
Rāhavacanda saw Jaṇaddaṇa.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.29.8.1)
Hence, O Karṇa, I tell you this teaching (advice) again.' (\textit{Mahābhārata} 8.28.8e)

The Lord alone reigns [over time and death and this universe of mobile and immobile objects], this truth I tell you.' (\textit{Mahābhārata} 5.66.13c)\footnote{The previous line of verse completes the translation: \textit{kālasya ca hi mṛtyoś ca jaṇgamasthāvarasya ca}  (\textit{Mahābhārata} 5.66.13a)}
I was spoken to by the beasts at night.' (\textit{Mahābhārata}  3.244.11a)

imt: thus, this.\textsc{nom.n.sg} tell-\textsc{perf.n.sg} all-\textsc{nom.n.sg} I.\textsc{ins.sg} you.\textsc{dat/gen.pl} great.sage.\textsc{voc.pl}
src: tad etat kath-itaṃ sarv-aṃ mayā \textbf{vo} munisattamāḥ
trs: Thus, I have told you all this, O great sages.'  (\textit{Mahābhārata} 1.20.12a)
(He) showed the image of Sita on a screen (painting) to Bhāmaṇḍala.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.21.8.9)
I have told you this great secret.' (\textit{Paumacariu}  1.16.8.9)
She garlanded Kikkindha (lit.\ put a garland on)' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.7.4.1)

imt: send-\textsc{perf.m.sg} letter.\textsc{nom.m.sg}  chief-\textsc{dat/gen.sg} Anaraṇya-\textsc{dat/gen.sg} Ayodhyā-\textsc{dat/gen.sg} king-\textsc{dat/gen.sg}
trs: (He) sent a letter to  Anaraṇya, the king of Ayodhya' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.15.8.4)
(After) I handed her the finger ring, having bowed to her, (she) gave me this precious gem.'   (\textit{Paumacariu} 3.55.9.7)
I have given my daughter to the son of Dasaraha (Daśaratha).' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.21.11.4)

imt: then, sky-\textsc{abl} descend-\textsc{ger}  Añjanā-\textsc{dat/gen.sg} Vasantamāla.\textsc{nom} meet-\textsc{perf.f.sg}
trs: Then, having descended from the sky, Vasantamālā met Añjanā.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.19.8.10)
The king will drive out the sages.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.35.9.1)
The messenger told (this) to Ravana, who was capable of causing the eight territories (\textit{aṣṭapada}) to tremble.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.15.4.1)
They showed (the boys) to the lord of Pamiṇipura (Padminipura), the king Vijayaparvata.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.33.2.1)
O warrior (Lakshmana), please forgive me one time' (\textit{Paumacariu} 3.44.4.7)
O beautiful one, look at the battle.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.31.12.3)
When they were denouncing Jiṇinda thus, the seat of Dharaṇinda started to shake.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.2.14.5)
I will attack Dūsaṇa' (\textit{Paumacariu} 2.40.4.10)

imt: run-\textsc{perf.m.sg} aṅkusu.\textsc{nom.m.sg} lakṣmaṇa-\textsc{dat/gen.sg} attack-\textsc{perf.m.sg} lavaṇa.\textsc{nom.m.sg} battlefield-\textsc{loc.sg} rāma-\textsc{dat/gen.sg}
src: dhā-iu aṅkusu lakkhaṇ-aho    abbhi-ṭṭu lavaṇu raṇ-e \textbf{rām-aho}
trs: Aṅkuṣa ran to Lakshmaṇa (while) Lavaṇa attacked Rāma' (\textit{Paumacariu} 5.82.14.13)
At some places (on the battlefield), she-jackals approached the (dead) warriors.' (\textit{Paumacariu} 1.17.13.8)
Having spoken thus, taking him by the hand, she took him to her house.' (\textit{Līḷācaritra} 1.34)
Therefore, even by the strength of light, they do not see me.' (\textit{Dnyāneśvarī} 7.25.158)

imt: then self-\textsc{gen.n.sg} deed.\textsc{nom.n.sg} proclaim-\textsc{impf.3.pl} and world-\textsc{acc} denounce-\textsc{impf.3.pl}
src: maga āpu-leṃ keleṃ phokār-itī āṇī  \textbf{jagā=teṃ} dhikkār-itī
trs: Then they proclaim their own deeds and denounce the world.' (\textit{Dnyāneśvarī} 16.10.328)
